content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Longer than 5 mins, but doable in less than 10 mins.
I'd like to see it on a clash

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's fun challenging, a bit hard but not impossible, takes times to cover some edge case.

The only little downside I think it may be too difficult to be a fun "shortest" clash
Mmaybe state how many B is KiB, and how many KiB is Mib ect.
feel free to specify the rounding strategy
It could be worth adding a more detailed explanation of the unit system in the statement, you have specified 1024B is 1KiB but you should also clarify that 1024KiB is 1MiB rather than 1000KiB is 1MiB

Hello,
Interesting and useful.. But, one question... In "Out of space test", is it normal if there is "TB" instead of "TiB"?

Input section
* Please specify that each line contains a float and a unit separated by a space, and the unit may be one of these: {{B}}, {{KB}}, {{MB}}, {{GB}} and {{TB}}.

Output section
* Please define "binary prefix".
* ... and Wikipedia states that "KiB", "MiB", etc are also classified under "binary", which is even confusing if you do not put in any definitions required by the clash.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byte
It looks like you are calculating based on power of 2 but using the units based on power of 10.

Constraints section
* [[Sizes]] is not defined anywhere in the statement. It is not used in the stub generator either.

Thanks.

Thank you for your very detailled comment, this means a lot to me !
Everything you mentionned has been updated.
Nope, this indeed was a silly mistake, thank you for pointing it out !
I thought this was pretty explicit.. sorry if it wasn't. I added clarifications, thank you for letting me know about your issue !
Clarifications were added, thanks for your feedback.
This is already mentioned within the output section.

This JS stub mistake isn't one: due to the nature of a variable declared using var, declaring the same one once again is equivalent to replacing it. Not a pretty choice by the codingame team imo, but it should not cause any issues with your code : ) 

Regarding the shortest feedback, I think I will have to agree with you. I have attempted solving the puzzle this way when I created it and it took me quite some time - I think more than 15 minutes - so I will try again and see depending on my performance whether I keep it or not.

Thank you for your feedback, this means the world to me ! : )

Your statement...

"The output will always have at most one decimal point in this puzzle, so there is no need for rounding."

... doesn't tell people what to implement. Instead it's a very loose description of a characteristic of the test cases input data.

I think it would be overly complicated in this challenge to clearly state the input limitation, so I think it would be much better replace this with an explicit description of a rounding strategy.

So if you clearly state a rounding strategy and include a test to test for it, that will likely be much easier for everyone to grok and code for.

for example that statement could be replaced with: "If the answer is none integer it should be rounded down to 1 decimal place"
Thank you for your comment, I've changed this part of the constraints section, do you think it is clear enough now ?
